VP CONJUNCTION CORPUS

The VP Conjunction corpus is a subset of the upcoming PDTB 3.0 corpus, that can be used either on its own or, like the PDTB 2.0 corpus, in conjunction with the Penn TreeBank. The early release here is for the benefit of the research community, whose feedback will also help inform the development of the final version of PDTB 3.0.

Click here to download the VP Conjunction corpus.

Description and File Format

The downloaded corpus should unzip into a directory containing two top-level subdirectories:
  • ann
  • annText
ann contains the main annotation files presented in the newer PDTB 2.0 pipe-delimited format, as described within the tools page. Users with access to the 1989 Wall Street Journal text corpus used by Penn Treebank II will only need the files within this folder.

As before, the annotation files are distributed within subdirectories corresponding to sections of the Penn Treebank. Seven new fields have been added to the original pipe-delimited format and these are marked in blue in the table below:

Description of fields within ann files
Relation TypeExplicit, Implicit, AltLex, EntRel, NoRel
Conn SpanText Span of the Connective
Conn SrcConnective's Source
Conn TypeConnective's Type
Conn PolConnective's Polarity
Conn DetConnective's Determinacy
Conn Feat SpanConnective's Feature Span
Conn1Explicit Connective / First Implicit Connective
SClass1AFirst Semantic Class of the First Connective
SClass1BSecond Semantic Class of the First Connective
Conn2Second Implicit Connective
SClass2AFirst Semantic Class of the Second Connective
SClass2BSecond Semantic Class of the Second Connective
Sup1 SpanText Span of the First Argument's Supplement
Arg1 SpanText Span of the First Argument
Arg1 SrcFirst Argument's Source
Arg1 TypeFirst Argument's Type
Arg1 PolFirst Argument's Polarity
Arg1 DetFirst Argument's Determinacy
Arg1 Feat SpanText Span of the First Argument's Feature
Arg2 SpanText Span of the Second Argument
Arg2 SrcSecond Argument's Source
Arg2 TypeSecond Argument's Type
Arg2 PolSecond Argument's Polarity
Arg2 DetSecond Argument's Determinacy
Arg2 Feat SpanText Span of the Second Argument's Feature
Sup2 SpanText Span of the Second Argument's Supplement
Adju ReasonThe Adjudication Reason
Adju DisagrThe type of the Adjudication disagreement
PB VerbThe PropBank verb of the main clause of this relation
PB RoleThe PropBank role of the PropBank verb
IdentifierThe unique identifier of this token within the annotation file
TaskThe name of the task for which the token was annotated
LinkThe link id of the token

annText is provided for users who do NOT have access to the Wall Street Journal corpus. The files within the annText directory contain raw text corresponding to the Arg1 and Arg2 spans of each token as well as the text of the sentence(s) containing these arguments.

The directory structure within annText mirrors that of the ann directory. Files within annText also follow a pipe-delimited scheme with one token per line. Users may relate a token in an annText file to its associated token in the corresponding ann file based on a common Identifier field, as described in the table below.

Description of fields within annText files
Relation TypeExplicit, Implicit, AltLex, EntRel, NoRel
IdentifierThe unique identifier of this token - corresponds to the Identifier field in the ann files
Conn TextThe text of the Explicit connective or the AltLex span
Arg1 TextThe text of Arg1
Arg2 TextThe text of Arg2
Sentence TextThe text of the sentence(s) containing Arg1 and Arg2
LinkThe link id of the token - correspond to the Link field in the ann files

Linking

In the VP-Conjunction corpus, the arguments of an explicit conjunction may also be related by additional discourse relations which could be conveyed implicitly or by an explicit discourse adverbial. In the example below, the explicit conjunction and co-occurs with an additional implicit relation instead:

We've got to get out of the Detroit mentality and Implicit=instead be part of the world mentality, declares Charles M. Jordan, GMâ€™s vice president for design (Expansion.Conjunction & Expansion.Substitution.Arg2-as-subst) [wsj 0956]

The annotation convention for cases as the above is to annotate two tokens, one explicit and the other implicit. To capture the association between the two tokens, the Link field is populated with a string made up of the keyword LINK followed by a numerical index. Linked tokens will share the same link values. The annotations for the tokens in the above example are shown below, with the link index (LINK3) marked in bold:

Explicit|5947..5950|Wr|Comm|Null|Null|||Expansion.Conjunction| .... |5947..5950|VP-CONJ|LINK3
Implicit||Wr|Comm|Null|Null||instead|Expansion.Substitution.Arg2-as-subst| .... |5947|VP-CONJ|LINK3

Tool

Users with access to the Wall Street Journal text files may choose to visualize the VP Conjunction annotations using the latest version of the PDTB Annotator. Please note that the annotation files will be editable when loaded into this tool, so proper care should be taken to avoid mistakenly updating the annotations in the corpus.

To learn more about and to download the tool, please visit the PDTB Annotator page.

For questions/comments, please contact Alan Lee at aleewk AT seas.upenn.edu
